title: In a horror setting, what is the difference between terror, scary, and creepy? - Quora

response.answer_text: Here’s what I think is a defining moment of terror. It sneaks up on you but unlike a jump scare, it’s usually a series of events or moments that when put together, it creates a fear that slowly builds along with realization of the moments coming together and the fear builds in concert with the mental calculation of the situation.  So, scary is a moment. Walking in on a scene and that moment, cranks up your nerves and you immediately get the fear response. And it could anything from blood splattered walls to a lone doll in the middle of a long hallway. And it can be a piece of the puzzle that leads to terror.   Creepy, can also be a moment but can also just be a feeling. Just seeing a person standing still on a streetwithout moving, a pitch black room or an abandoned house can create the moment that we call creepy.  Because you never know if this moment might turn into this..  Anyway, this is just what I think. I have clearly watched way to many scary movies to have this deep of an opinion about moments.

there can be a lot of different kinds of things…like take blair witch project…or saw…totally terrifying…you could have a haunted house…escape from new york…the guy was going to die if he didn’t do what the boss wanted…many different elements of terror and creepy…u could see bad deformity…scary demons…creepy people…a dark ally…people with creepy manerisms…a place with a homicide scene…different body parts all over the place…finding dead people if you go on a walk or explore somewhere…i can go on and on…i love horror and the macabre…there is many different kinds of fear and horror…even..the real kinds you can see on live leak…if faces of death wasn’t enough…it depends on how you use it…you can enhance things using them at the right kinds of times…
